case_data.name: De La Fuente v. Hobbs
case_data.plaintiff_description: Alliance Party and the Alliance Party's Presidential Nominee for the 2020 Presidential Election
case_data.summary: The Alliance Party, a national political party, and their 2020 presidential nominee, Roque "Rocky" De La Fuente, filed this case in the United States District Court for the District of Arizona on June 29, 2020, seeking to modify Arizona's signature collection and witnessing requirements for independent and third-party presidential candidates. The plaintiffs sued the Secretary of State of Arizona under the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the U.S. Constitution for declaratory and injunctive relief regarding the state's signature requirement in light of the COVID-19 pandemic and the state's restrictions on non-essential activities. The plaintiffs alleged in their complaint that, based on Arizona's ballot measures, the Alliance Party would need to collect 39,039 signatures to secure access to the 2020 general election ballot for president and vice president. While an electronic signature system is available in Arizona, plaintiffs argued that it would be impossible to communicate with voters without in-person contact. The plaintiffs also alleged that the Governor of Arizona's March 30 stay-at-home order, which was not lifted until May 12, prevented them from collecting signature's in-person by limiting in-person activities to essential functions. In addition, the plaintiffs argued that the signature ballot put their own petition circulators at risk of contracting COVID-19. The plaintiffs contended that the state's signature collection requirement, combined with COVID-19 restrictions and dangers, impaired their rights under the First and Fourteenth Amendments. They claimed that the signature requirement was not narrowly tailored to advance a compelling governmental interest during the pandemic and that the plaintiffs would suffer irreparable injury unless the requirement was lifted. The plaintiffs sought preliminary and permanent injunctive relief prohibiting the defendant from strict enforcement of the state's signature requirements. As an alternative to the current signature requirement, plaintiffs requested a lowered signature requirement of 3,904 or a filing fee of $5,000. The plaintiffs also sought a declaration that the signature requirements are unlawful as imposed against independent and third-party candidates during a public health emergency under the First and Fourteenth Amendments. The case was assigned to Judge Michael T. Liburdi. On October 2, 2020, the plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed their action. The case is now closed.
case_data.summary_short: In June 2020, the Alliance Party and their nominee for the 2020 Presidential Election filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona. The plaintiffs alleged that Arizona's signature requirement for third-party candidates, in light of the COVID-19 pandemic, violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments. The plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed their complaint in October 2020. The case is now closed.
case_data.summary_tiny: In June 2020, the Alliance Party and their nominee for Presidential Election filed this complaint alleging that Arizona's signature requirement for third-party candidates, in light of the COVID-19 pandemic, violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments.

documents.title: Civil Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
documents.text:
Case 2:20-cv-01276-MTL   Document 1   Filed 06/29/20   Page 1 of 28
 
1  Morgan J. C. Scudi (SBN 013403) 
Scudi & Ayers 
2 
5440 Morehouse Drive 
3  Suite #4400 
San Diego, CA  92121 
4 
Phone:  858.558.1001 
5 
Fax:   858.558.1122 
6  mscudi@scudilaw.com 
 
7 
 
8 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR 
9  THE DISTRICT OF ARIZONA 
 
10 
ROQUE โROCKYโ DE LA FUENTE,  Case No.: __________ 
11 
and ALLIANCE PARTY, 
12 
 
                     Plaintiffs,  CIVIL COMPLAINT FOR 
13 
  DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE 
14 
vs.  RELIEF 
15 
KATIE HOBBS, in her official capacity 
16 
as the Secretary of State of Arizona, 
17 
Defendants.
 
18 
 
  1.  Plaintiffs, by and through their undersigned legal counsel, file this 
19 
20 
action seeking prospective declaratory and injunctive relief and to modify Arizonaโs 
21 
signature collection and witnessing requirements as applied to independent and 
22 
23  third-party presidential candidates seeking to qualify for the November 3, 2020, 
24 
Arizona general election ballot as a direct consequence of the current and ongoing 
25 
COVID-19 pandemic.   The Governorโs emergency orders effectively shutting down 
26 
27 
the  State  of  Arizona  from  March  to  June  and  the  social  distancing  protocols 
28 
CIVIL COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF - 1 
 

Case 2:20-cv-01276-MTL   Document 1   Filed 06/29/20   Page 2 of 28
 
1  employed by federal and state governments to combat the spread of COVID-19 and 
2 
the long-term fear and unwillingness of individual voters to be approached by 
3 
strangers requesting that they sign election petitions in violation of social distancing 
4 
5 
norms  drummed  into  their  heads  by  federal,  state  and  local  officials  through 
6 
executive orders, proclamations, press conferences and the nearly ubiquitous media 
7 
8  advertising  purchased  both  by  government  agencies  (such  as  the  CDC)  and 
9 
commercial businesses seeking to glom on to the โStay Home Stay SafeโฆWe Are 
10 
In This Togetherโ mantra make it functionally impossible to collect the over 39,000 
11 
12 
signatures required to secure ballot access for independent and third-party candidates 
13 
for Arizonaโs November 3, 2020 presidential election. 
14 
15    2.  On April 23, 2020, Judge Rebecca R. Pallmeyer of the United States 
16 
District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, preliminarily enjoined the number 
17 
of signatures required to place the name of an independent candidate on the 2020 
18 
19 
general election ballot by reducing the number of signatures required to secure ballot 
20 
access to 10% of the normal statutory requirement as a result of the social distancing 
21 
22  and  stay-at-home  orders  issued  to  stem  the  transmission  of  the  novel  Wuhan 
23 
coronavirus in Illinois.  See, Libertarian Party of Illinois v. Pritzker, 1:20-cv-02112, 
24 
Doc. No. 27 (N.D. Ill, J. Pallmeyer, April 23, 2020). 
25 
26 
  3.  In support, Plaintiffs need only allege obvious and indisputable facts โ  
27 
that the signature collection requirement imposed by Section 16-341 of the Arizona 
28 
CIVIL COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF - 2 
 

Case 2:20-cv-01276-MTL   Document 1   Filed 06/29/20   Page 3 of 28
 
1  Revised Statutes on independent and third-party presidential candidates should be 
2 
held unconstitutional for the 2020 presidential election as a result of the ongoing 
3 
pandemic which makes it functionally impossible for independent and third-party 
4 
5 
presidential candidates to collect the required number of valid signatures to secure 
6 
ballot access for the 2020 Arizona general election. 
7 
8    4.  Excessive ballot access requirements impair โcore political speechโ of 
9 
both candidates and voters afforded the highest level of constitutional protection 
10 
under the First and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution. 
11 
12 
  5.  Under the current pandemic conditions and restrictions, as applied to 
13 
access to the 2020 presidential general election ballot, the requirements imposed on 
14 
15  independent and third-party presidential candidates by A.R.S. ยง16-341 impose a 
16 
temporary severe restriction on rights guaranteed under the First and Fourteenth 
17 
Amendments to the United States Constitution which are not narrowly tailored to 
18 
19 
advance  a  compelling  governmental  interest  during  an  ongoing  public  health 
20 
emergency  and  its  immediate  aftermath  and  are  unconstitutional  and  must  be 
21 
22  immediately enjoined and/or modified. 
23 
  6.  Accordingly,  Plaintiffs  respectfully  request  that  this  Court  enjoin 
24 
Defendant from strictly enforcing A.R.S. ยง16-341 for the 2020 general election and 
25 
26 
provide complete relief in the form of an order requiring Defendant to print Plaintiff 
27 
De La Fuenteโs name on the 2020 presidential ballot if Plaintiff either: (1) timely 
28 
CIVIL COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF - 3 
 

Case 2:20-cv-01276-MTL   Document 1   Filed 06/29/20   Page 4 of 28
 
1  files, in addition to all other documents required to be filed, a nomination petition 
2 
containing 10% of the number of valid signatures required to secure ballot access 
3 
under A.R.S. ยง16-341; or, in the alternative, (2) timely pays a filing fee, in addition 
4 
5 
to all other documents required to be filed, of $5,000.00 to Defendant on or before 
6 
4:00 p.m. on September 4, 2020, in lieu of the signature collection requirement 
7 
8  imposed by A.R.S. ยง16-341. 
9 
JURISDICTION 
10 
  7.  Jurisdiction lies in this Court under 28 U.S.C. ยง 1331, providing that 
11 
12 
the district courts of the United States shall have original jurisdiction of all civil 
13 
actions arising under the Constitution of the United States. 
14 
15    8.  Moreover, jurisdiction lies under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 and 28 U.S.C. ยง 
16 
1343(a), the jurisdictional counterpart of 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 as Plaintiffs allege a 
17 
violation of rights guaranteed to them under the United States Constitution. 
18 
19 
VENUE 
20 
  9.  Venue is proper in the United States District Court for the District of 
21 
22  Arizona under 28 U.S.C. ยง 1391(b) because a substantial part of the events and 
23 
omissions giving rise to Plaintiffsโ claims occurred in this district.  Furthermore, 
24 
Defendant exercises her statutory authority within this district and maintains her 
25 
26 
principal office within this district. 
27 
 
28 
CIVIL COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF - 4 
 

Case 2:20-cv-01276-MTL   Document 1   Filed 06/29/20   Page 5 of 28
 
1  PARTIES 
2 
  10.  Plaintiff Alliance Party (hereinafter sometimes โPlaintiff Alliance Partyโ 
3 
or โAlliance Partyโ) was created on October 14, 2018, at a meeting in Denver, 
4 
5 
Colorado when three political parties, the American Moderates Party, the Modern 
6 
Whig Party and the American Party of South Carolina, agreed to merge to create the 
7 
8  Alliance Party.  On January 4, 2019, the Alliance Party officially registered with the 
9 
Federal Elections Commission.  Thereafter, the Independence Party merged with the 
10 
Alliance Party in 2019; the American Alliance Party merged with the Alliance Party 
11 
12 
in 2019 and in 2020, the Independent Party of Connecticut formally merged with the 
13 
Alliance Party. 
14 
15    11.  Plaintiff Alliance Party is governed by the Alliance Party National 
16 
Committee.  Jim Rex is the Chairman of Plaintiff Alliance Party National Committee.  
17 
Plaintiff Alliance Partyโs mailing address is P.O. Box 1354, Anacortes, WA  98221. 
18 
19 
  12.  On April 25, 2020, Plaintiff Alliance Party conducted an online national 
20 
convention  and  formally nominated  Plaintiff  Roque  โRockyโ  De La  Fuente  of 
21 
22  California as its 2020 nominee for the Office of President of the United States and 
23 
Darcy Richardson of Florida as its 2020 nominee for the Office of Vice President of 
24 
the United States.  Owing to automatic ballot status in certain states, Plaintiff 
25 
26 
Alliance Partyโs presidential ticket secured immediate ballot access for the 2020 
27 
general election in Delaware, South Carolina, Mississippi and Florida.   
28 
CIVIL COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF - 5 
 

Case 2:20-cv-01276-MTL   Document 1   Filed 06/29/20   Page 6 of 28
 
1    13.  Plaintiff Roque โRockyโ De La Fuente (hereinafter โPlaintiff โ), is the 
2 
2020 nominee of Plaintiff Alliance Party for the Office of President of the United 
3 
States. 
4 
5 
  14.  Plaintiff  De  La  Fuente  intends  to  seek  ballot  access  for  the  2020 
6 
presidential general election in every state where is he permitted to secure ballot 
7 
8  access. 
9 
  15.  Plaintiff De La Fuente is over the age of 35, is a natural born citizen of 
10 
the United States of America, having been born in San Diego, California and has 
11 
12 
been a continual resident of the United States for over 35 years. 
13 
  16.  Plaintiff De La Fuente satisfies all of the qualifications enumerated 
14 
15  under the Presidential Qualification Clause of Article II, section 1, clause 5 of the 
16 
United States Constitution. 
17 
   17.  Defendant Katie Hobbs is sued in her official capacity as the chief 
18 
19 
elections official of the State of Arizona and charged with enforcing Section 16-341 
20 
of the Arizona Revised Statues.  Defendant Hobbs is the supervisor and director of 
21 
22  all election matters in Arizona and is sued for declaratory and injunctive relief under 
23 
42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 and 28 U.S.C. ยง 2201, as well as costs and attorneyโs fees under 
24 
25  42 U.S.C. ยง 1988(b). 
26 
  18.  At all relevant times, Defendant is engaged in state action under color 
27 
of state law. 
28 
CIVIL COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF - 6 
 

Case 2:20-cv-01276-MTL   Document 1   Filed 06/29/20   Page 7 of 28
 
1  FACTS 
2 
  19.  Plaintiff Alliance Party nominated their national ticket on April 25, 
3 
2020. 
4 
5 
  20.  Plaintiff Alliance Party nominated Plaintiff Roque โRockyโ De La 
6 
Fuente as their 2020 nominee for the Office of President of the United States. 
7 
8    21.  In Arizona, presidential candidates who do not seek to run under a 
9 
recognized political party label may be nominated to appear on the general election 
10 
ballot by gathering the required number of signatures on nomination petitions from 
11 
12 
registered voters.  Once the candidate designates his or her vice-presidential running 
13 
mate and completes other required paperwork, the candidateโs name (along with the 
14 
15  candidateโs chosen label) will appear on Arizonaโs 2020 presidential general election 
16 
ballot alongside the recognized party nominees. 
17 
  22.  Section 16-341(E) & (F) of the Arizona Revised States provides the 
18 
19 
signature  requirements  and  deadlines  imposed  on  independent  presidential 
20 
candidates to gain access to Arizonaโs general election presidential ballot: 
21 
22  (E)  The nomination petition shall conform as nearly as possible to the 
provisions relating to nomination petitions of candidates to be voted for 
23 
at primary elections and shall be signed by at least the number of 
24  persons who are registered to vote determined by calculating three 
percent of the persons who are registered to vote of the state, county, 
25 
subdivision or district for which the candidate is nominated who are not 
26 
members of a political party that is qualified to be represented by an 
27  official party ballot at the next ensuing primary election an accorded 
representation on the general election ballot. 
28 
CIVIL COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF - 7 
 

Case 2:20-cv-01276-MTL   Document 1   Filed 06/29/20   Page 8 of 28
 
1   
(F)  The percentage of persons who are registered to vote necessary to 
2 
sign the nomination petition shall be determined by the total number of 
3  registered voters from other than political parties that are qualified to 
be represented by an official party ballot at the next primary election 
4 
and accorded representation on the general election ballot in the state, 
5 
county, subdivision or district on January 2 of the year in which the 
6  general election is held.  Notwithstanding the method prescribed by 
subsection E of this section and this subsection for calculating the 
7 
minimum number of signatures necessary, and person who is registered 
8  to  vote  in  the  state,  county,  subdivision  or  district  for  which  the 
candidate  is  nominated  is  eligible  to  sign  the  nomination  petition 
9 
without regard to the signerโs party affiliation. 
10   
  23.  On January 2, 2020, there were 1,301,292 registered voters in Arizona 
11 
12 
who were not registered in a political party qualified to be represented by an official 
13 
party ballot at the next primary election and accorded representation on the 2020 
14 
15  general election ballot. 
16 
  24.  As of June 18, 2020, Plaintiff Alliance Party is not a political party 
17 
qualified in Arizona to be represented by an official party ballot at the next ensuing 
18 
19 
primary election. 
20 
  25.  Based on information published on Defendantโs official website, only 
21 
22  the Republican, Democratic and Libertarian parties are qualified to nominate their 
23 
presidential candidates by an official party ballot at the next ensuing primary election. 
24 
  26.  Accordingly,  Plaintiff  Alliance  Party  must  collect  39,039  valid 
25 
26 
signatures from registered voters on nomination petitions to secure access to the 
27 
2020 general election ballot for Plaintiff Alliance Partyโs presidential and vice 
28 
CIVIL COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF - 8 
 

Case 2:20-cv-01276-MTL   Document 1   Filed 06/29/20   Page 9 of 28
 
1  presidential nominees. 
2 
  27.  Pursuant  to  A.R.S.  ยง16-341(G),  Plaintiff  Alliance  Party  must  file 
3 
nomination petitions to place the name of Plaintiff De La Fuente on the 2020 general 
4 
5 
election ballot no later than the sixtieth day before the general election. 
6 
  28.  For the November 3, 2020, presidential general election, the deadline 
7 
8  for Plaintiffs to file their nomination petition is 4 p.m. on September 4, 2020. 
9 
  29.  Pursuant to A.R.S. ยง16-341(M), Defendant also permits nomination 
10 
petitions to be signed electronically through the stateโs โE-Qualโ system. 
11 
12 
  30.  Despite the availability of the โE-Qualโ system, there is no reasonably 
13 
available method to permit Plaintiffs to contact Arizona voters to communicate their 
14 
15  candidacy and the requirement for them to sign their nomination petition through the 
16 
stateโs โE-Qualโ system without engaging in direct person-to-person contact. 
17 
  31.  Accordingly,  the  stateโs  โE-Qualโ  system  is  not  a  reasonable, 
18 
19 
constitutional  substitute  to  the  person-to-person  contact  between  Plaintiffsโ 
20 
circulators and Arizona voters necessary to secure the 39,039 valid signatures to 
21 
22  qualify for the 2020 presidential general election ballot. 
23 
  32.  Collecting signatures by hand, on paper nomination petitions, through 
24 
face-to-face solicitation is inherently burdensome, labor-intensive and inefficient as 
25 
26 
a means of demonstrating voter support.  Many signatures are often invalidated due 
27 
to illegibility, missing information and other mere technical defects.  This obligates 
28 
CIVIL COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF - 9 
 

Case 2:20-cv-01276-MTL   Document 1   Filed 06/29/20   Page 10 of 28
 
1  candidates and political parties to collect at least 25% to 50% more signatures than 
2 
required, in order to account for those signatures that might be later invalidated.  In 
3 
fact, in other states, such as Virginia, the Virginia Board of Elections expressly 
4 
5 
recognize that candidate should collect at least 50% additional signatures above the 
6 
minimum number by instructing candidates:  โBecause people who are not registered 
7 
8  to vote often sign petitions for candidates, we recommend that you collect at least 
9 
7,500 signatures. . . .โ  See, VIRGINIA STATE BOARD OF ELECTIONS โHOW TO RUN 
10 
11  FOR OFFICE FOR INDEPENDENT OR THIRD PARTY POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS: 
12 
BALLOT ACCESS REQUIREMENTS FOR THE NOVEMBER 3, 2020 GENERAL ELECTION 
13 
FOR PRESIDENT AND VICE PRESIDENTโ at p. 9. 
14 
15    33.  Accordingly, the number of raw signatures that Plaintiffs need to collect 
16 
to secure ballot access for the 2020 Arizona presidential general election is between 
17 
48,000 and 58,000. 
18 
19 
  34.  Colorado and Oklahoma have opted to impose a filing fee instead of 
20 
signature collection requirements for presidential candidates in order to protect their 
21 
22  legitimate interest to limit access to their general election ballot and to prevent ballot 
23 
clutter and voter confusion: 
24 
    (a)  Colorado imposes a $1,000 filing fee, due August 5, 2020;  
25
